Remarks

In what follows, as well as throughout in Reverse Proxy, we consider the following picture as illustrative of the Proxy.

     +-------------------+
     |  Destination      +
     +-------------------+
           ▲       |
       (b) |       | (c)
           |       ▼
     +-------------------+
     |      Proxy        +
     +-------------------+
           ▲       |
       (a) |       | (d)
           |       ▼
     +-------------------+
     | Client            +
     +-------------------+

(a) and (b) show the request path, going from the client to the target. (c) and (d) show the response path, going from the destination back to the client.

Normal proxying comprises the following steps: (0) Disable ASP .NET Core limits for streaming requests (1) Create outgoing HttpRequestMessage (2) Setup copy of request body (background) Client --► Proxy --► Destination (3) Copy request headers Client --► Proxy --► Destination (4) Send the outgoing request using HttpMessageInvoker Client --► Proxy --► Destination (5) Copy response status line Client ◄-- Proxy ◄-- Destination (6) Copy response headers Client ◄-- Proxy ◄-- Destination (7-A) Check for a 101 upgrade response, this takes care of WebSockets as well as any other upgradeable protocol. (7-A-1) Upgrade client channel Client ◄--- Proxy ◄--- Destination (7-A-2) Copy duplex streams and return Client ◄--► Proxy ◄--► Destination (7-B) Copy (normal) response body Client ◄-- Proxy ◄-- Destination (8) Copy response trailer headers and finish response Client ◄-- Proxy ◄-- Destination (9) Wait for completion of step 2: copying request body Client --► Proxy --► Destination

ASP .NET Core (Kestrel) will finally send response trailers (if any) after we complete the steps above and relinquish control.
